title: Evaluating the impact of hydroxychloroquine on mouse lymphocyte proliferation and cytokine production in vivo and in vitro
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Mouse treatment and single cell suspension of splenocytes
Timing: 6 days
For this protocol, we will describe the treatment of mice and splenocyte isolation for further analysis of lymphocyte functions.
Treatment of 8 weeks old mice with hydroxychloroquine by daily gavage
Prepare 5 mg/mL HCQ in deionized water and gavage mice with 100 μL daily
On the 6th day, euthanize mice and harvest spleens following institutional animal guidelines. The spleens should be kept in 1× PBS on ice until further steps.
Create a single cell suspension of splenocytes by the following steps.
Place the spleen in a 6 well plate with some 1× PBS to keep spleen wet.
Prepare a 50 mL tube with a 5 cm × 5 cm square of 40 μm nylon mesh.
Homogenize the spleen with the end of a plunger from a 5 mL syringe, tamp the spleen against the bottom of the 6 well plate.
Add 10 mL of 1× PBS to the well of the plate in step 2 to resuspend.
With a 10 mL serological pipette, filter the splenocyte solution through the nylon mesh into the 50 mL tube.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 7 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 2 mL of ACK lysing buffer for 3 min at 25°C.
Add 10 mL of 5% FCS in 1× PBS to the RBC-lysed splenocyte solution.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 7 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the splenocytes in 5 mL of 1× PBS.
Gather a new 15 mL tube and a 5 cm × 5 cm square of 40 μm nylon mesh.
Filter the splenocyte solution through the nylon mesh into the 15 mL tube

Optional: To distinguish the effects of treatment on lymphocyte function in different organs you can also harvest the liver, lymph nodes or blood from the mice. To create a single cell suspension of hepatic lymphocytes please refer to (Yoneyama et al., 1998[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]), for lymph nodes lymphocytes to (Lim et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]) and for blood lymphocyte separation to (Spranger et al., 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Optional: For additional investigation of cell exhaustion upon HCQ or other treatments you can add anti-PD-1, Tim3 and CD69 to the extracellular master mix and stain unstimulated lymphocytes.
Treatment of stimulated lymphocytes
Timing: 8 h
Here we describe the PMA/ionomycin stimulation experiment. For this experiment use splenocytes previously isolated from either HCQ treated or untreated mice.
Key step: count splenocytes to ensure the final number of cells per well.
Take desired cell number and spin down at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Dilute splenocyte at a final concentration of 2×106 splenocytes/mL in lymphocyte media
Add 100 UI/mL (final concentration) of IL-2 to lymphocyte media to make completed lymphocyte media
Seed 100 μL of cell suspension in 96 V-bottom plate
Pause Point: Use splenocytes from untreated mice to test the effects of in vitro HCQ treatment on splenocytes.
Prepare the treatment media by adding HCQ (molecular mass 319 g/mol) to completed lymphocyte media as shown in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
table:files/protocols_protocol_626_5.csv
Add 50 μL of the HCQ treatment media to each well of the splenocytes of untreated mice and use technical triplicates for every HCQ concentration.
Prepare the stimulation media by adding 8 μL/mL stimulation mix (PMA/ionomycin)
Add 50 μL of stimulation media to in vivo HCQ treated splenocytes or in vitro HCQ treated splenocytes as well as controls (the final concentration of stimulation mix is 2 μL/mL). Use one sample as unstimulated control.

Pause Point: Now you have in vitro stimulated splenocytes in 200 μL, splenocytes from in vivo treated mice in 150 μL and unstimulated controls in 100 μL (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

L/D, Live/Dead
Add 50 μL completed lymphocyte media to splenocytes of treated mice and 100 μL to the unstimulated controls
Incubate splenocytes in 37°C for 4 h
Spin down plate at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Wash once with FACS buffer and discard the supernatant
Critical: If you want to adapt this protocol, avoid centrifuge steps and other manipulations before the incubation of splenocytes to minimize the risk of cell death and improve cytokine signaling.
Optional: Additional marker for cell exhaustion such as anti-PD-1, Tim3 and CD69 could be added to this panel to further investigate the influence of medications on lymphocytes.
Stain for flow cytometry analysis
Prepare Live/Dead (L/D) stain by adding 1 μL/mL L/D stain to PBS
Resuspend cells in 50 μL L/D stain and incubate for 20 min in 4°C
Add 150 μl FACS buffer to each well and spin down plate at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Resuspend cells in 50 μL extracellular antibody master mix and incubate for 15 min in the dark at RT.
Add 150 μl FACS buffer to each well and spin down plate at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Resuspend cell in 100μL of BD Bioscience Fix/Perm and incubate at 4°C in the dark for 30 min
Spin down plate at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Resuspend cells in 50 μL intracellular antibody master mix and incubate for 15 min in the dark in RT

Add 150 μl FACS buffer to each well and spin down plate at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Dilute cells in 150 μl FACS Buffer for analysis for flow cytometry analysis
Analyze data using FlowJoTM software
Optional: To get a better insight of the lymphocyte cytokine production profile, different concentrations of the stimulation mix can be applied. The recommended final concentration is 2 μL/mL but we observed positive TNFα and IFNγ signaling starting from a concentration of 0.5 μL/mL.
Proliferation and cytokine production of treated lymphocytes after antigen-specific activation
Timing: 2–3 days
For this protocol we describe how to evaluate antigen-specific cytokine production as well as lymphocyte proliferation using CFSE stained OT-1 lymphocytes.
Sacrifice one 8 weeks old OT-1 mouse following institutional animal guidelines and harvest the spleen
Create a single cell suspension as described in step 2.
Resuspend 5×107 splenocyte cells in 10 mL prewarmed 0.1% BSA/PBS in 50 mL tube
Add 5 μL of a 5 mM stock solution CFSE on the wall of the 50 mL tube and vortex
Put the 50 mL tube in a water bath 37°C for 6 min
Stop CFSE staining of cells by adding 25 mL FSC
Centrifuge the tube at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Wash cells once with completed media
Resuspend cells in completed lymphocyte media (see step 6) and resuspend cells with a final concentration of 2×106 splenocytes/mL
Seed 100 μL per well of the cell suspension in a 96 well flat bottom plate
Prepare treatment media as described in step 7
Prepare stimulation media by adding 4 μg/mL OVA-I peptide to completed lymphocyte media (final concentration 1 μg/mL)
Add 50 μL of stimulation media to splenocytes. Use one sample as unstimulated control.

Add 50 μL of treatment media to splenocytes.
Note: In this experiment, it is crucial to add P/S to the media as the incubation time is longer and the risk for infection higher. Again, avoiding centrifuge steps until the incubation improves viability of the cells and consistency of the results.
Incubate splenocytes in 37°C for 2 days
Spin down plate at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant
Save the supernatant to perform ELISA analysis following vendor’s instructions
Wash pellet once by adding 5 mL PBS, centrifuge at 400 g, 4°C, for 7 min and discard the supernatant.
Perform an extracellular staining of cells for flow cytometry analysis as described in Step 15. Dilution of CFSE can be detected with the FITC channel.
